growth of the peripheral parts since these may be entirely detached from
it, without any loss of vital activity. The same inference may be
deduced from the examination of specimens, in which, the central
portion of the disk having been broken-out, a growth of new zones
seems to have taken place from without inwards, so as to fill up the
void space thus left. In no other way can I account for the
appearance presented by the specimen delineated in Fig 7, in
which the included portion is as evidently unconformable to that
which surrounds it, as it is in the preceding case, but in which
there is also an unfilled void, the shape of one part of which clearly
indicates that it occupies the site of the original centre. <u>Note</u> [the
course of the zones still left, clearly indicates that the disk must
have been one of those with a very eccentric nucleus, resembling those
in Plate XI, Figs 1. 2. 10]  The <u>included</u> portion, and not the
peripheral, must therefore be the after-growth in this instance;
and it seems to have proceeded inwards from the zone <u>a, a, a</u>,
in the line of which the fracture probably ran. Had a little more
time elapsed, the whole of the central vacuity could probably
have been filled-up by this new growth.
